Expectation1: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation1: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: A fellow activist is live-streaming from a small demonstration right now and has asked for more people to show up if they are free.
Story: I parked my scooter in front of the quiet house, the package balanced on my arm. The instructions were clear: leave it at the doorstep, take a photo, and make sure it’s safe. I glanced at my phone, ready to snap the proof, when a notification popped up—a message from Maya, my friend from the activist group. “We’re at the square now, live. Police are circling. Can you come?” My heart thudded. I’d promised to help today, to stand with them and show the city we wouldn’t be ignored. But the package in my hand was expensive, and the company tracked every delivery. If it went missing, I’d be blamed. I looked at the empty street, then at the stream on my phone—faces I knew, voices I cared about, chanting for justice. My job demanded I finish the route, secure every parcel. My conscience pulled me toward the protest, to be present, to matter. I stood frozen on the porch, torn between duty and conviction, the weight of both roles pressing down on me.
